52040f29-653c-45ed-8407-79a2c0f315c7.description: Tableau is an Analytic and Business Intelligence platform that is widely used by business analysts. Essential Tableau Skills earners have demonstrated foundational knowledge of the Tableau Desktop software to analyze data and share their insights. They are able to prepare and filter data to create different data visualizations, apply analytics to solve business problems, and build interactive dashboards to communicate their findings.
52040f29-653c-45ed-8407-79a2c0f315c7.name: Essential Tableau Skills

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Participants complete a business analytics course, which includes hands-on use of Tableau.

6d5edc78-4fbb-46f1-8e70-3820096a2a5a.description: Earners developed an understanding of lean process improvement (LPI) techniques, which are heavily influenced by Japanese and US production and organizational leadership philosophies. Participants applied core concepts to create an initial LPI plan for an institutional operation of their choosing, with a focus on international programs. The plans use LPI methods to substantially decrease workload, reduce errors and obtain a higher student yield (without expanding budgets or staff).
6d5edc78-4fbb-46f1-8e70-3820096a2a5a.name: Lean Process Improvement & Institutional Operations

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Earners participated in five interactive Lean Process Improvement (LPI) workshops focusing on systems thinking, waste management, and program planning. Participants developed LPI plans to improve efficiency, using value-stream mapping and metrics for the international operation of their choosing and presented to the other participants for critique and improvement.

6fb66cf8-51fb-4137-80af-37cbea312d51.description: The Emerging Nonprofit Leadership Accelerator (ENLA) microcredential is designed to cultivate a robust talent and leadership pipeline for the nonprofit sector in the greater Capital Region and beyond. Participants engage in team-building, professional soft skills workshops, technical trainings facilitated by subject-matter experts, and receive one-on-one mentorship/career coaching to prepare for future leadership roles.
6fb66cf8-51fb-4137-80af-37cbea312d51.name: Emerging Nonprofit Leadership Accelerator

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Workshop #1 - StrengthsFinders 2.0 - Participants learn the value of a strengths and asset-based approached - versus a deficit-based approach - when building themselves, their teams, their organizations, and their communities. Using the CliftonStrengths assessment, participants discover their own unique strengths and explore how those strengths serve them and others.

Workshop #2 - Strengths-Based Leadership - Participants explore the full range of 34 strength themes, how those strengths fit into 5 leadership areas, and the advantages of having a full range of strengths on your team.

Workshop #3 - Boards and Governance - What unique characteristics define a non-profit? What is the role and responsibility of the board? Who should serve on a board and how can one prepare for board service? What is the role of an executive director vis-a-vis the board and how can you build and manage an effective board? This introduction to boards and governance explores these and other issues.

Workshop #4 - Nonprofit Finance - This workshop focuses on the unique financial and reporting requirements that govern nonprofits. Participants learn how to use Guidestar, how to read and interpret 990s, and how to run ratios to monitor their nonprofit's financial health.

Workshop #5 - Development and Fundraising - This workshop introduces participants to the importance of developing a strategic fundraising plan, review the various forms of fundraising and their respective return on investment, and drive home the importance of donor mining, management, and retention.

Workshop #6 - Marketing and Communications - Participants learn how to identify their audiences, develop a strategic marketing plan, use multiple mediums, build a brand, and tell the story of your organization in order to drive growth and engage clients, donors, and volunteers.

Workshop #7 - Human Resources through an Equity Lens - This workshop focuses on the fundamentals of HR function with a particular eye toward the recruitment, on-boarding, retention, and succession of a vibrant and diverse workforce.
Workshop #8 - Managing Yourself, People, and Projects - This workshop is filled with tools, tips, and technologies for organizing yourself, your teams, and your projects for greatest impact.

Workshop #9 - Motivating Your Team: Driving and Measuring Impact - Participants learn the art and science behind building and developing teams to realize their greatest potential and impact. Emphasis is placed on understanding your role as a leader based on your team's experience, capability and performance.

Workshop #10 - Effective Workplace Communication: Getting and Giving Feedback - Participants assess their communication style and practice how they can more effectively communicate with their teams. Focus is placed on offer feedback to, and requesting feedback from, subordinates, colleagues, and supervisors.

Workshop #11 - Collaboration and Partnership - This workshop examines the range of partnerships and collaboration, why an organization might benefit from such arrangements, the pitfalls of the partnership process, the need to identify and engage a broad range of stakeholders, and the potential for collective impact models to lead to systems change.

Workshop #12 - Change Management - Significant change is not possible unless all stakeholders are engaged in the process. This workshop uses John Kotter's fable, "Our Iceberg is Melting," to examine the many roles leaders, staff, and community members play in advancing, or stalling, organizational change, and the importance of developing a coherent, clear, and persuasive rationale, vision, and strategy that brings everyone along in the process.

Workshop #13 - Analyzing Systemic Power in the Nonprofit Sector - This workshop invites participants to consider the role of nonprofits in the United States and the systems that nonprofits wittingly and unwittingly support, benefit from, and perpetuate including systemic oppression and racism. The session touchs on the nature of charity and philanthropy, the "nonprofit industrial complex," and the need for systems change.

Workshop #14 - Crucial Conversations about Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion - This workshop focuses on anti-racism and healing justice. Participants explore their own biases, develop awareness of organizational practices, and find the voice to be powerful proponent of anti-racism in their workplaces and communities.

Workshop #15 - Path to Executive Director - This final workshop gives participants an opportunity to explore the rewards and challenges of nonprofit leadership with mentors in the field and consider their own career goals and trajectory.

e235325d-e5df-4641-b413-67dad1e8c7f5.description: Earners are both senior and line officials responsible for building and sustaining strategic relationships between international students, alumni, and families to promote internationalism for their university. The earner has developed critical management skills to lead, plan and manage an effective global alumni engagement strategy adapted to their campus and professional needs. They can communicate the value proposition of the program and align internal priorities to support the alumni plan.
e235325d-e5df-4641-b413-67dad1e8c7f5.name: Global Alumni Relations

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Earners engaged in five instructor-led sessions and additional collaborative sessions with fellow participants developing leadership, management, and planning skills in global alumni management. Participants create a 12 month project plan to effectively manage and communicate the value proposition of global alumni relations for their specific university.

ae6f778f-ec86-4dca-9073-4614c692a2af.description: Learners have developed a comprehensive understanding of Student and Exchange Visitors Program (SEVIS) and key compliance elements. The participant can use this knowledge and understanding to revise and draft new institutional policies to incorporate best practices and anticipate, manage and mitigate the major risks to the institution, students, and scholars they serve. Using a critical-incident approach, learners can create operational solutions for compliance and risk management situations.
ae6f778f-ec86-4dca-9073-4614c692a2af.name: Immigration Compliance, Policy Development and Risk Management

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Learners participate in five interactive classes which address the key compliance elements of SEVIS and risk management. Working in small groups based on their current institutional roles, participants revise and draft new institutional policies, producing a Policy Definition, International Student Employment Policy, International Visitor Policy and Operational Compliance Plan.

ebd578db-7d68-41a3-93a1-2eb71c379c34.description: Learners explored the critical aspects of developing and sustaining strategic and productive international partnerships as it relates to their own institution. Through analysis of case studies, learners examined common models of structuring, contracting and evaluating international partnerships and the infrastructure needed to do so. They also developed protocols for leading and hosting international delegations, as well as tracking and reporting on international activities.
ebd578db-7d68-41a3-93a1-2eb71c379c34.name: International Education Partnerships

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Learners are existing International Education professionals who participated in five interactive virtual workshops reviewing the role of partnerships in global engagement strategies and reviewing current partnerships at the learner's organization. As a culminating project learners developed an International Partnership rubric to evaluate and structure prospective international partnerships, develop contracts, and operationalize these relationships, and track and report international activities.

1770201e-3493-4258-9552-2601c5c36ae2.description: The Three Minute Thesis (3MT®) cultivates graduate students' academic, presentation, and research communication skills. Earners are UAlbany research master’s and doctoral students who have demonstrated the development of research communication skills and showcased these skills through participating in the UAlbany 3MT Competition.
1770201e-3493-4258-9552-2601c5c36ae2.name: Three Minute Thesis: Communicating Research to Broad Audiences

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Session 1 (1-hour) - Communicating to a Non-Specialist Audience - This session covers 1) how to find a hook to get audiences interested in their research, 2) how to frame your research and focus on the most compelling aspects of the work, and 3) make a strong case for your work's importance to non-specialist audiences.

Session 2 (1-hour) - Pitch + Presence - This session covers 1) how to visually communicate, 2) how to capitalize on your reputation and sound credible when presenting, 3) how to feel more comfortable speaking in front of groups, and and how to 4) communicate with impact

Session 3 (1-hour) - Data Visualization – This session covers 1) how to effectively design and use a PowerPoint slide to support an oral presentation 2) how to let your slide speak for itself or direct the audience to your slide, and 3) common pitfall to avoid when utilizing a PowerPoint slide.

Session 4 (1-hour) - Presentation Zen - This session brings the first three modules together to 1) help the learner to limit text on their slide, 2) make their presentation visual and 3) tell their story in three minutes.

365bd453-181a-4b50-a9cb-777c058d180e.description: Data analytics is a discipline focused on extracting insights from data. It comprises the processes, tools and techniques of data analysis and management, including the collection, organization, and storage of data. Earners take a practical approach to common techniques for understanding and deriving knowledge from data. Self-paced online content will cover concepts needed to understand how to gather data, process it and derive understanding from data by using data analytics tools and formulas.
365bd453-181a-4b50-a9cb-777c058d180e.name: Data Analytics Fundamentals

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Earners generate Descriptive and Inferential Statistics on the data, several visualizations, and develop a regression model of a real-world problem.

031a401b-4954-4292-a655-7fe845fe39f1.description: Learners develop the skills and disciplines needed to make critical informed decisions in international education through the Management Accounting framework. Participants examined international education scenarios and identify the financial and qualitative data analysis needed for a decision. Earners also examined risks factors and ethical issues associated with specific decisions.
031a401b-4954-4292-a655-7fe845fe39f1.name: Data-Driven Decision Making in International Education

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Learners engaged in five interactive online workshops to develop decision making skills through the use of data analysis, both quantitative and qualitative. Throughout the course, participants  analyzed and reflected on four international education scenarios using the management accounting framework, to create a final report showing the decision making process through the use of careful analysis.

3f91d370-96e2-4f26-b0d8-489f854f58f4.description: This microcredential is for nonprofit professionals tasked with finding grant funds for their organizations. Earners develop the skills and knowledge required for successful grant prospecting, grant writing, and grant management.
3f91d370-96e2-4f26-b0d8-489f854f58f4.name: Nonprofit Grant Writing

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Module 1 - Grant Prospecting that Works: This module provides strategies for grant prospecting activities that make the grant writing process more efficient and effective. Participants will learn new strategies for developing current or future grants programs, creating more efficiency in the grant application process, and better understanding the importance of prospecting as part of the overall grants strategy.

Module 2 - Grant Writing for Success: Review common grant application types, the pros and cons of each grant type, and some general information about how to structure and write successful grant proposals to varied audiences (e.g., governmental, foundation, corporate). Discuss the Case Statement/Case for Support and its impact on the overall grant writing process.

Module 3 - Strategies for Successful Grant Management: Review the important aspects of a quality grant management program. This includes the common requirements to prepare for after securing a grant from various funding sources (government, foundation, corporate). Sample tools will be provided and discussed for their applicability to grant programs. Emphasis will be placed on compliance and strategies that move organizations from compliance to collaborative relationships with funders.
Submit a written case statement tailored to a grant prospect for a nonprofit organization.

df5147b1-dbbb-451e-8461-ea99dc80c3c3.description: As current international education professionals, learners collaborated editorially to develop effective written communication about international education. Earners have mastered "nut graphs" and other writing organizational techniques to marshal facts, organize ideas, and craft effective arguments to advance understanding among key audiences and stakeholders, in accordance with the Standards of Professional Practice put forth by Association of International Education Administrators.
df5147b1-dbbb-451e-8461-ea99dc80c3c3.name: Communicating International Education

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Learners participated in five interactive virtual workshops which explored the most effective communication methods for addressing stakeholders in international education. Working in pairs or small groups, earners create a nut graph, which summarizes the essence of a piece and draws interest, for the international education topic of their choice and refine and edit based on collaboration with their team.  This nut graph is assessed by the instructor for clarity, relevancy and effectiveness.

skills.name: "Nut Graph" And Other Writing Organizational Techniques

9ad95627-fd2d-451b-8117-aecbfaedbc86.description: The ongoing demographic shift in the global workforce has demanded an intentionality from leaders and managers to ensure organizational viability moving forward. This microcredential is designed to provide learners with the concepts and practices that are foundational to being culturally and equity responsive. Over the three modules, the learners explore aspects that influence effective diversity, equity, inclusion, and sense of belonging.
9ad95627-fd2d-451b-8117-aecbfaedbc86.name: Fundamentals of Diversity, Equity, Inclusion & Sense of Belonging (DEIS) for Professionals

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Module 1 - Historical and Foundational Aspects of Diversity, Equity, Inclusion and Sense of Belonging - Introduces learners to key historical events, including legal events that have influenced practices of DEIS in the workplace. Morril Act, Fair Housing Act, Civil Rights Act of 1964, Title IX are discussed to provide context of current practices today. This session covers foundational understanding of protected classes and literacy surrounding equal employment opportunity.

Module 2 - Dialogue Across Difference - Combines experiential activities and small group discussion based on the philosophy of Intergroup Dialogue. Participants earn skills in active listening, suspending judgment, leaning into discomfort, and using empathy as way to be more culturally responsive in work environments. Learners have a better sense of their own identity and how power, privilege, and oppression interplay with those who they supervise and lead.

Module 3 - "The Influence of DEIS in the Workplace" - Emphasizes the strategic benefits of DEIS in successful teams and organizations. This session helps learners differentiate between performative/reactive actions and impactful, enduring initiatives focused on engaging all employees, improved climate, and sense of belonging and the creation of high functioning teams.

5f7c2839-14aa-4eba-8b2e-f82a4f7b48a8.description: Earners of this microcredential have mastered the fundamentals of information technology and possess essential skills that employers are seeking in professionals across a broad range of information environments. Earners participated in three modules presenting graduate-level instruction in topics, such as Python or R, relational databases, data visualization, and networking protocols. Skills were applied to an experiential capstone project focusing on advanced programming and web technologies.
5f7c2839-14aa-4eba-8b2e-f82a4f7b48a8.name: Fundamentals of Information Technology

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: To earn the microcredential, students must complete at least 3 of the 4 modules and submit an experiential learning capstone project based on one or more of the modules offered in Informatics (INF 523) by the College of Emergency Preparedness, Homeland Security, and Cybersecurity.

f813de51-cc60-4ba6-8bc7-2a21bac29222.description: Social Media Influencer Marketing allows learners to discover how to develop, manage and evaluate a successful social media influencer campaign using influencers to help grow a business. This online, self-paced program helps participants identify why harnessing the power of quality social media content and storytelling is vital to engagement and building trust. Earners practice digital skills that enable them to develop a high-impact influencer strategy on social media.
f813de51-cc60-4ba6-8bc7-2a21bac29222.name: Social Media Influencer Marketing

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Participants create a video reflecting their developed social media influencing strategy for a social media platform of their choosing.

a24ffb3b-3133-4fb0-a68b-783c9a269283.description: Learners developed a plan to use technology and digital learning to create new and reshape existing programs in international education to meet students’ global learning needs and increase resilience to environmental risks. By identifying current technology, learning and organizational resources on campus, participants can develop connected approaches including virtual exchange and shared network strategies, which to integrate into their own virtually connected internationalization strategies.
a24ffb3b-3133-4fb0-a68b-783c9a269283.name: Connected Strategies for International Education

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Learners participated in five interactive virtual workshops which addressed analysis of of virtual and organizational resources and international program needs to create a global connectivity strategy.  Working with fellow participants to develop global education virtual strategies, they created an individual global connectivity initiative for their institution and prepare an advocacy argument for its implementation.

fe54c726-3f00-4d59-bb14-45f5f2f9d970.description: The earner of this microcredential in Improvement Science Leadership is a leader and practicing professional who can engage in systemic improvement initiatives. This earner can act as a change agent and galvanizer for improvement in their organizational settings. Settings typically include education and other social sector organizations.
fe54c726-3f00-4d59-bb14-45f5f2f9d970.name: Improvement Science Leadership

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Complete two 3-credit graduate courses (EEPL/ETAP 641 Continuous Quality Improvement in Education and Human Services, and EEPL/ETAP 663 Networked Communities: Building A Culture of Practice Improvement) and a 1-credit capstone experience.
Develop an improvement plan, which will be presented in the capstone course.

b9191b02-7691-4276-9f76-4dd23d795da6.description: Earners are nonprofit board members, employees, or volunteers with a nonprofit or community organization, or small business operators. Earners developed critical skills necessary to manage marketing initiatives designed to connect with constituents, clients, community members, board members, employees, and volunteers with the goal of publicizing events, promoting their mission, and conducting fundraising campaigns. This knowledge was used to develop a marketing strategy for their organization.
b9191b02-7691-4276-9f76-4dd23d795da6.name: Marketing Management

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Modules are centered on developing a marketing strategy, including managing their website, utilizing social media channels, and designing email marketing campaigns. Earners have delivered a tangible representation of their developed marketing strategy with insight and review from instructor and program peers.

253de135-6537-4b11-9a07-3d51a4cb0611.description: This micro-credential is designed for international education professionals, leaders, and future leaders needing tools and strategies for taking their institution to a higher level of international engagement, regardless of their starting point or institutional stature. Through specific exercises, readings, and projects in this rigorous module, participants develop both professional skills and valuable deliverables to implement changes to international education operations in their own settings.
253de135-6537-4b11-9a07-3d51a4cb0611.name: (Re)positioning International Offices

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Virtually, learners grouped by interest and institution type assess current institutional status and devise 1-3 year (Re)positioning Plans to strengthen the international office and its overall contribution to campus-wide internationalization. Learners will: Session 1. Use SWOT analysis to explore key elements of curricular internationalization.
Session 2. Use Reverse Engineering to re-envision institutional offerings, redefine the international office and its campus position to start drafting the re-positioning plan.

Session 3. Investigate financial challenges and produce arguments for funding international office initiatives with options such as traditional and non-traditional student financial aid, brainstorming new revenue streams, building campus allies, and reframing budgets in an investment framework to reduce program fees and attract new funding.
Session 4. Identify operational and management strategies to take advantage of student strengths, both international and domestic, as well as staff training and mentoring.
Session 5. Present final (Re)positioning Plans and collectively critique. The learner’s (Re)positioning plan is evaluated by the instructor for purposes of awarding the digital badge.

f862d87b-21f6-415a-b47a-e50b72d733dc.description: Intro to Mobile App Design takes learners through a self-paced online course that describes the process that developers go through to go from idea to functional mobile app. This program covers the entire app design process from creating a product brief and defining an idea to designing and creating a prototype. Earners practice course concepts through the development of a pitch deck and mobile app prototype.
f862d87b-21f6-415a-b47a-e50b72d733dc.name: Mobile App Design

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Earners create a pitch deck and a mobile app prototype.

9d20e06d-dcbf-4c8a-b9f9-fb5714deb656.description: Social Media Management is a self-paced online program that prepares participants to plan, execute, and assess ways to use social media to collaborate and communicate more effectively. Learners develop skills that allow them to maximize talent, energy, knowledge, and innovation from customers and employees using social media. After completing this course, badge earners are able to capitalize on online community building and authentic communication in an ever-changing digital world.
9d20e06d-dcbf-4c8a-b9f9-fb5714deb656.name: Social Media Management

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Earners develop a social media post prototype that demonstrates digital leadership skills.

2e7bdc25-f8b8-4870-8002-355f998392b1.description: Artificial Intelligence (Al) has permeated our everyday lives, automating systems and occupations that once required humans to function. Al has had tremendous benefits to the advancement of modern technology and has provided insight into data sets of unfathomable size. This self-paced, fully online program allows earners to examine the history of Al, break down the various sub-fields, uncover the algorithms, and focus their vision for the future.
2e7bdc25-f8b8-4870-8002-355f998392b1.name: Artificial Intelligence Fundamentals

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Earners develop a journal documenting knowledge of Al systems and its applications. In the final section of the journal, participants provide a detailed analysis of a system or technology that applies to their current job, research or creative interest and describe a particular application of Al that could optimize and/or improve this system or technology.

335792c5-75b7-4156-9fd4-3c1fc6406d05.description: Cloud Computing with Microsoft Azure is a self-paced online program that covers the fundamental concepts needed to understand cloud computing on the Microsoft Azure platform. Azure is a cloud computing service created by Microsoft for building, testing, deploying, and managing applications and services through Microsoft-managed data centers. Earners deploy a simple web application to the Azure platform where they can see the application run in a web browser.
335792c5-75b7-4156-9fd4-3c1fc6406d05.name: Cloud Computing with Microsoft Azure

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Participants are asked to demonstrate and use Microsoft Azure. Earners take the Hello World web application introduced in the course and customize it based on the project instructions, deploy the web application to the earner's Azure web application service, test the application in their browser to see that it is deployed to the Azure cloud and available on the Internet.

95a301c9-2fdb-47f1-8c52-18fad4ee162e.description: International education crises can take many forms, from dealing with specific health and safety matters for students abroad, as well as macro-level challenges such natural disasters, cybersecurity, terrorism, and pandemics. As current international education professionals, learners explored how to evaluate and prioritize risks and existing response policies, prepare for a potential international crises, and lead an institutional response through the development of a Crisis Management Plan.
95a301c9-2fdb-47f1-8c52-18fad4ee162e.name: Crisis Leadership in International Education

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Learners participated in five interactive virtual workshops, which introduced the Emergency-to-Crisis continuum and identified and studied specific international risks. Strategies for risk mitigation and institutional crisis organization were discussed in small groups. Using this information, learners created a Crisis Response Plan for an institution/organization of their choosing with feedback from their colleagues and review by the instructor for clarity, relevancy and effectiveness.

skills.name: Conducting Policy Audits For International Risk

f9ebb837-61e9-4c3e-9874-7a5b432344ad.description: Python is a powerful programming language, yet can be learned rather quickly. Python is commonly used in industry for data analysis and rapid-prototyping. In this self-paced online course, participants learn the fundamentals of the Python language through an iterative, tutorial-based approach, and are able to solve problems on their own. Earners of the Solving Problems with Python badge implement a Python program that demonstrates skill development.
f9ebb837-61e9-4c3e-9874-7a5b432344ad.name: Solving Problems with Python

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Earners implement a Python program that demonstrates knowledge of the course learning objectives. The learner's final project is tailored to their current job, research, or creative interest.

7e94494d-5121-4aaf-a6bc-69c1a955cb11.description: Earners are both senior and line officials responsible for building and sustaining education abroad programs and services. Participants can identify and analyze key trends in education abroad and outline approaches, strategies, models, resources, and practices to keep education abroad a high value offering in higher education. As architects of the future of education abroad, earners have developed a five year strategic management plan for their institution.
7e94494d-5121-4aaf-a6bc-69c1a955cb11.name: Education Abroad- Trends, Strategies & Tactics

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Earners engaged in five instructor-led sessions and additional collaborative sessions with fellow participants developing leadership, management, and planning skills to create a strategic roadmap for the future of education abroad at their specific organization.  They identified key information sources and tools to track trends in education abroad to determine the impact to campus, organization, partners and programs.

4e80edb2-5cbc-4147-ad33-7e74b86d2a5a.description: Every organization should consider how to build and sustain a stakeholder-driven strategic plan to chart a thoughtful future course, improve impact, increase sustainability, and respond to constantly evolving environments and markets. This microcredential touches on all the fundamentals of a strategic planning process, from preparation and stakeholder engagement, through the creation of measurable and time specific annual operating plans, to implementation and evaluation.
4e80edb2-5cbc-4147-ad33-7e74b86d2a5a.name: Strategic Planning for Nonprofits

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Module 1 - How to Build and Sustain a Mission and Stakeholder-Driven Strategic Plan - What is a strategic plan and why do we engage in planning? This module includes a review of key concepts and the strategic planning process, from identifying and engaging stakeholders to developing goals and developing, implementing, and evaluating a multi-year work plan that is responsive to the rapidly changing environment we live in.

Module 2 - You've Committed Your Organization to Strategic Planning... Now What? - In this hands-on module, learners discuss the use of specific tools and activities leading to the identification of thematic goal areas, practice developing concise, clear, implementable, SMART and mission-based goals, and develop supporting objectives for their organization's work plan.

Module 3 - How to Ensure Your Strategic Plan Doesn't Sit on the Shelf and Collect Dust - This module focuses deeply on developing annual operating or work plans for your goals and objectives. Learn about the use of dashboards to keep their strategic plan front-and-center at staff and board meetings and consider strategies for holding themselves and each other accountable for the success of the plan.

f22d5ada-e25f-4a34-a06f-55b7402367a2.description: This microcredential explores various topics related to creating a person-first approach in your organization to gain a sense of understanding, recognize where there are opportunities for growth, and identify tools and resources, all while empowering you to move your organization forward. Learners explore building a person-centered organizational structure, human capital, organizational belonging, workforce development, burnout, and committing to a culture of change and elevation.
f22d5ada-e25f-4a34-a06f-55b7402367a2.name: Taking A Person First Approach in Organization Operations

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Module 1 - Have You Taken Your People into Account Lately? – Understand the need to align people with organizational goals to achieve engagement, retention, and succession. Participants consider the organizational health of their organization and explore concepts of how individuals impact organizational development, success.

Module 2 - Transforming from Employee Engagement to People Experience - An environment of inspiration and productivity requires organizations to create a space where people feel connected, valued, and motivated. Learners will identify ways to assess their organization's operations, policies, and benefits to see if they are meeting their people's needs.

Module 3 - Workforce Development: Beyond the Onboarding Process - Explore why workforce development is essential and what it looks like beyond general onboarding to ensure engagement, retention, and internal succession. In addition to general knowledge, the module explores action-based ideas and techniques.

Module 4 - Elevating Organizational Operations & Structures to Reduce the Impacts of Burnout - Discuss the operational and structural causes of burnout and potential impacts on the workplace, team dynamics, and people experience. This module also includes topics and techniques to create change organizationally and as a leader.

ef53bfe3-f57a-4124-b48e-409b3f899a2c.description: Earners of the eSports micro-credential have an understanding of eSports and the digital gaming ecosystem and a perspective of traditional sports in society. Through hands on experience as an intern working in a large eSports gaming facility for 100+ players, earners develop improved communication skills, critical thinking, resourcefulness and adaptability - as supported by the University of Glasgow 2017 study on skill development through video games - which can be used to further their careers.
ef53bfe3-f57a-4124-b48e-409b3f899a2c.name: eSports

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Earners successfully complete, with a grade of B or above, two courses enabling participants to gain a thorough understanding of eSports and the social impact of sports. This knowledge is applied through an academic internship in the eSports Gaming Lab. Learners create a final video project featuring live gameplay broadcast and archived gameplay video with custom graphics and commentary, a culmination of technical and professional skills developed.

fd124a86-bee9-42ac-acb5-339c53effba0.description: This microcredential focuses on foreign credential evaluation in the strategic international enrollment management environment. Learners examine the history of foreign credential evaluation, its evolution in the US, and the growth of this skillset into a new profession. Learners also practice the practical application of foreign credential evaluation skills in international education scenarios.
fd124a86-bee9-42ac-acb5-339c53effba0.name: Foreign Credential Evaluation

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Five 90-minute synchronous sessions with the instructor
4.5 hours of asynchronous sessions where participants prepare their final project

0a672c1b-d86c-498d-b6d4-25c640d71c8b.description: The Organizational Solutions for Diversity, Equity, Inclusion and Sense of Belonging microcredential provides participants in mid-level and senior leadership roles with strategies to create twenty-first century, culturally responsive workspaces which include high functioning diverse teams and improve diversity, equity, inclusion and sense of belonging (DEIS) outcomes.
0a672c1b-d86c-498d-b6d4-25c640d71c8b.name: Organizational Solutions for Diversity, Equity, Inclusion and Sense of Belonging

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Module 1 - Culturally Responsive Needs Assessment of Workplace Climate - Helps learners identify the best assessment strategies for understanding their organization's climate. Participants are introduced to key assessment strategies which provide a representative context of organizational climate. Participants learn proven techniques and practices for assessing the views, attitudes, and sentiments of stakeholders at all levels of the organization.

Module 2 - Best Practices for DEIS Strategic Planning - Provides learners with effective DEIS strategic planning methods that ensure measurable, meaningful, and enduring organizational outcomes. Learners are able to clearly differentiate actions from strategies and will gain the information needed to play a facilitative role in organizational DEIS development and positive change.

Module 3 - Effective Diverse Talent Acquisition Strategies – Learners develop talent acquisition and recruiting strategies that help them realize their organization's aspirational talent acquisition goals. This module focuses on intentional, high impact practices that are evidenced based, measurable, and enduring. Participants walk away with artifacts and tools that will aid in realizing their diverse talent acquisition goals.

421267c8-6188-4d5f-8c21-913450978ad3.description: In this microcredential, learners become familiar with basic development design concepts and tools that can be used to develop models of planned web or mobile applications, and will have the opportunity to acquire skills in the practice of user interface design, wireframing and mockup development, and the use of current prototyping tools for simulating user interactions and experiences.
421267c8-6188-4d5f-8c21-913450978ad3.name: Prototyping and Development of Web and Mobile Applications Using No-Code Tools 

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Module 1 - Design Basics: Getting Started with Brainstorming an Application - Provides an overview of basic web and application design terms and an introduction to usability and accessibility considerations in technology design.

Module 2 - Understanding the Assignment: Knowing your Who's and Why's - Concentrates on considering users in design; presents strategies to determine user types for various web/mobile applications, establishing user goals and how web/mobile applications can help achieve them, writing user stories to represent how proposed applications will support user goals.

Module 3 - Wireframes and Mockups – Provides a step-by-step introduction to creating low-fidelity and high-fidelity wireframes and mockups of user interface views for a system. Mapping user interface elements back to user stories will be presented.

Module 4 - Interactive Prototyping – Provides a step-by-step introduction to creating an interactive prototype that allows a walkthrough of the actions that would be taken by a user to achieve their goals as outlined in a user story. Mapping of interaction represented in prototype to wireframes/mockups is presented.

2f9916c4-3302-45c2-892e-81615c032541.description: In this self-paced online course, participants learn how to write and publish a book, the publishing process from beginning to end, how to create a book plan and outline, and how to print a book and get it into stores like Barnes & Noble, Amazon, Walmart, etc. The book publishing process is broken down into 6 stages; planning, writing, designing, formatting, publishing, and marketing. Participants develop a book plan and outline for their own project.
2f9916c4-3302-45c2-892e-81615c032541.name: Self-Publishing

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Earners develop a book plan and project outline addressing the six areas of self-publishing: planning, writing, designing, formatting, publishing, and marketing. Earners demonstrate understanding and basic competency in these skill areas.

672d939d-c0f9-4825-ab35-39d5df75e2cf.description: Earners have acquired competencies in the interdisciplinary fields of astro/particle physics, general relativity and cosmology. Participants have developed skills to create computational models to solve complex physics problems and generate data. Through analysis and study to create research papers and presentations, students can address critical problems and research within these modern fields using critical thinking and non-linear problem solving skills.
672d939d-c0f9-4825-ab35-39d5df75e2cf.name: Astro/Particle Physics

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Students must demonstrate a deep understanding of astro/particle physics and astronomy by achieving a B or higher in four related physics courses chosen out of five options.  Students create a portfolio of research term papers and presentations, and data generated by computational models to address complex problems in these modern fields.

0aeaa131-0f36-404c-9744-ca50f050fce2.description: This microcredential focuses on leadership development for new or experienced leaders of nonprofits or small businesses, with emphasis on how to manage one’s strengths and leadership style, and best practices for leading organizations including teamwork, communication, and coaching.
0aeaa131-0f36-404c-9744-ca50f050fce2.name: Coaching for Leaders and Managers

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Module 1 - Strengths Finder - This module focuses on identifying and building on the strengths of leaders. Learners explore the Clifton StrengthsFinder tool and how it can be applied, comprehend their own StrengthsFinder profile and how to use it in a leadership context, apply their profile in team-based homogeneous and heterogeneous groupings, and identify complementary strengths that will produce the best outcome for the organization.

Module 2 - Leadership Styles – Learners identify their leadership style is and how it can be used, discuss the context where the style can be used to optimal effect in a leadership setting, and apply their style in team-based homogeneous and heterogeneous groupings.

Module 3 - Emotional Intelligence – Leaners explore what explore emotional intelligence is and how it compares to other forms of intelligence, comprehend how emotionally intelligent leaders model such behavior in the workplace, and be able to apply personal and social competence, self-awareness and self-management and social awareness and relationship management.

Module 4 - Team Building – Learners use Patrick Lencioni’s Five Dysfunctions of a Team as the basis for conversation to distinguish effective teams from poor ones, explore techniques to overcome challenges in managing and forming common dysfunctions in their teams including: absence of trust, fear of conflict, lack of commitment, avoidance of accountability, and inattention to results.

Module 5 – Communication – Learners explore techniques to improve their communications skills and will craft an action plan to measure progress in the following areas: oral communication, written communication, electronic communication, and effective meetings.

Module 6 – Coaching – Learners will explore the basics of leadership coaching and its applicability in the nonprofit world, understand how they might apply a coaching dynamic in their own workplaces, model a simple coaching conversation, and prepare a coaching plan for their teams.

skills.name: Ability To Recognise And Develop One's Own Leadership Style

9810b8dd-ffb1-478b-aefb-04e9fbb94019.description: Successful fundraising is a critical component for almost all nonprofits and a required competency for nonprofit leaders. This microcredential is designed for executive directors, professional fundraising staff, and board members with more than two years of fundraising experience. Earners take a deep dive into six key areas for executive leadership: program evaluation, planned giving, board involvement, prospect research, capital/major gift campaigns, and grant writing.
9810b8dd-ffb1-478b-aefb-04e9fbb94019.name: Executive Level Fundraising for Nonprofits

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Module 1 - Program Evaluation - There are multiple ways to evaluate the health of your fundraising program beyond your total dollars raised. Often times, organizations focus solely on achieving a dollar goal that they are not paying close enough attention to other important metrics within their program. Participants review the top ten indicators every organization should know, discuss strategies to have a positive impact on these metrics, and integrate metrics in staff evaluation.

Module 2 - Planned Giving - Participants review simple will bequest language and effective marketing strategies, discuss creation of a Planned Giving Advisors committee and a Gift Acceptance Policy, and discuss donor advised funds and additional complex planned giving vehicles.

Module 3 - Board Involvement - An effective board of directors for any non-profit organization must be willing to share their time, talent and treasure. Boards of Directors have a fiduciary responsibility to the organization and play a critical role in advancing the mission of the organization. Participants review strategies for board member recruitment and retention and how to handle departures, review and discuss common expectations for board members, and discuss effective board governance.

Module 4 - Prospect Research - As organizations become more sophisticated, it is important to work as effectively as possible with donors and prospects. Prospect research is an important tool that empowers staff to learn more about their current donors and communicate with them more effectively. Participants discover cost-effective tools for prospect research, develop individual donor profiles for prospects, and develop individual donor cultivation, solicitation and stewardship plans.

Module 5 - Capital\Major Gift Campaigns - Participants discover basic components of a campaign effort, including feasibility studies, discuss important fundamental steps to take leading up to campaign efforts, and discuss hiring outside counsel, attracting and retaining staff and board member involvement.

Module 6 - Grant Writing - Grant writing is both an art and a science and requires planning, data collection, and data based projected outcomes. Grants are also important opportunities to support current programs within your organization. During this module, participants learn how to research grant opportunities, discuss data gathering and project evaluation techniques, and access on-line products to assess grant award probability.

97a77259-2cc4-486c-96c1-c7771844f45f.description: This microcredential is designed for any professional involved in any level of patient care, contact or program development within medical or patient care settings, and to enhance front end/mid-level professionals understanding of how to assess the functioning of first contacts with patients as a means of improving patient flow and preparation of documentation for other care team members. Earners also improve their assessment and interview tools to enhance effectiveness of patient care.
97a77259-2cc4-486c-96c1-c7771844f45f.name: Foundations of Clinical Interviewing

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Module 1 - The Semi-Structured Clinical Interview - Provides a foundation in clinical interviewing as it is carried out by various team members in a variety of settings, which symptoms are assessed for, and how this information is both related to and used by various team members. Direct examples of semi-structured interviews are reviewed with practice and assessment of each of these performed during this module.

Module 2 - Interdisciplinary Team Collaboration - Learners review clinical interview materials and approaches used in various settings, assessing these in relation to the goals of the setting the effectiveness of present interview styles and types in meeting those goals. Individual questions, scales and materials are reviewed. Learners independently research which tools are used at present and offer thoughts on their uses. This module includes a team assignment.

Module 3 - Semi-Structured Clinical Interview - Learners are provided information on a "real world" setting, and as a team develop a semi-structured clinical interview best suited for the setting and the identified individual and team needs. Learners present their interview, providing justification, anticipated outcomes, how it effectively serves their population, and perform a trial run of their clinical interview. Learners present how this interview meets system and program goals.

f0edbb80-662b-49bf-a7c8-16849feab094.description: Earners developed leadership skills to engage in systemic improvement initiatives in education and other social sector organizations. Improvement Science, championed by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching and Learning, has emerged as an evidenced-based process for affecting positive and lasting change. Participants can effectively use improvement tools and processes to address root causes of sub-optimal outcomes for students and identify drivers for improvement.
f0edbb80-662b-49bf-a7c8-16849feab094.name: Improvement Science for Organizations

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Earners participated in six interactive improvement science workshops focusing on inquiry, data analysis, and program evaluation. Participants developed a pilot project addressing a specific problem of practice at their current organization, utilizing skills obtained through the program.

36f037c2-a319-4517-b454-990633cc8fa0.description: In this microcredential, participants learn the fundamental mechanics, ethics, and strategies of effective fundraising, including developing, implementing, and evaluating your plan and building annual giving campaigns and special events that further your mission and engage and retain donors.
36f037c2-a319-4517-b454-990633cc8fa0.name: Introduction to Fundraising for Nonprofits

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Module 1 - Fundraising 101: The Mechanics, Ethics and Strategies of Raising Money – Learners discuss giving trends in the nonprofit sector, as well as learn basic fundraising tools and resources that will set an important foundation for the following workshops. Learners review basic fundraising terminology, discuss common donor motivations for giving, and review IRS polices that nonprofits must follow.

Module 2 - Unrestricted\Annual Giving: Building Sustainability at Nonprofit Organizations – Learners explore the importance of building a robust annual giving plan integrating with their marketing and communications efforts. Learners discover necessary components of an annual integrated calendar including direct mail, donor acquisition, digital communication, review/discuss trackable metrics beyond dollars raised to grow annual giving programs, and discuss growth strategies.

Module 3 - Special Events - Special events play an important role at every organization as they can be both important fundraising and friend raising tools. Although special events can be very labor intensive for the organization there are ways to make these events both effective and efficient. Learners review and discuss the components of a special events plan, discuss appropriate post-event follow-up, and discover creative ways to raise funds beyond the typical gala format.

Module 4 - Stewardship & Donor Relations - Showing appreciation to donors in the number one way to ensure donors keep giving to your organization. While thank you letters are important, effective stewardship is much more than a simple letter. Learners discover new, unique ways to steward donors to ensure donor retention, discuss effective language for stewardship messages, and review best practices and real-life examples of effective messaging.

Module 5 - Digital Fundraising - Organizations must have a digital presence across multiple platforms and strategize to maximize their exposure to grow their fundraising efforts. Learners discuss integrating a digital strategy within their fundraising strategies, discuss Facebook, Instagram, Snapchat and other potential platforms for digital presence and fundraising, and review best practice cases.

Module 6 - Building Your Fundraising Strategy: Planning, Assessment, and Evaluation – Learners understand how to build an annual fundraising plan and the small, smart, and successive steps you can take to improve overall results by evaluating fundraising program's true effectiveness, developing short and long-term goals based on current performance, planning for the next fiscal year, and operating a more effective organization which results in more philanthropic dollars.

489e3a64-1e59-4dba-815b-151233689260.description: Libraries are vital sources of social infrastructure and librarians have served as second responders during times of disaster or social unrest. Participants learned how to provide necessary and valuable services to their communities during times of crisis. Earners of this micro-credential developed an emergency response and reopening plan, demonstrating their ability to provide continuity of operations when interruptions take place.
489e3a64-1e59-4dba-815b-151233689260.name: Librarians as Second Responders

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Earners attended a 6 hour (1 day) training on the need for librarians as second responders following disaster with topics including crisis management and continuation of operations. Earners completed a pre and post assessment to judge their knowledge and created a sample emergency plan relevant to their current institution implementing new techniques learned in the training.

e88e6d41-766f-4111-88ec-fe0618bfab69.description: This online, self-paced program allows participants to gain the essential tools and strategies to critically consume and create information in a digital, social media-infused environment. Recipients of this badge have demonstrated vital competencies as self-directed and civic-minded metaliterate learners who ethically produce and share information with others in both academic and professional settings.
e88e6d41-766f-4111-88ec-fe0618bfab69.name: Metaliteracy

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Earners develop a digital resource of their choice (video, blog, podcast, webpage, etc.) that teaches others about the importance of ethical information use and creation in the context of their chosen field or daily life.

6cdd5d2c-569a-4ac4-b14e-c07c8f6d375b.description: This self-paced, online program teaches participants to become change agents to help organizations reduce their social and environmental impact. Learners discover the three pillars of sustainability, the UN Goals for Sustainable Development, the science behind climate change, and practical examples of how organizations are implementing strategies. Badge earners apply these principles by completing exercises at the end of each module and creating a final project proposal.
6cdd5d2c-569a-4ac4-b14e-c07c8f6d375b.name: Sustainability for Organizations

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Earners develop a detailed proposal for a sustainability project to be implemented for an organization of their choice.

f31209ca-fb15-45b9-b6df-aa27093d4263.description: This microcredential introduces ESG as a system. The components of environmental, social, and governance impacts can be identified as well as measured. This credential focuses on how those impacts are identified, measured, and reported within a dynamic environment that is exposed to external forces (e.g. climate change), the impact of which is not fully understood. Participants learn how to build ESG concepts into business plans and identify points of risk within a business's operations.
f31209ca-fb15-45b9-b6df-aa27093d4263.name: Understanding the Impact of Environmental Social Governance (ESG)

issuer.summary: issued by University at Albany, SUNY

badge_template_activities.title: Module 1 - Understanding Environmental Social Governance (ESG): The Fundamentals. This module covers ESG vocabulary (same words/different meaning), a high level overview of the impacts of ESG, materiality, and the current state of global ESG.

Module 2 - ESG Risk Management. This module covers points of risk within your business or operation, building ESG concepts into your business plan, business/marketing positioning using ESG, and becoming a local ESG leader.

Module 3 - Impact Investing. This module covers how and why ESG is scored, understanding the ESG scoring/matrix, social engagement and stewardship, responsibilities, and regulatory dynamics and the evolving responsibilities and mandates.

Module 4 - Future State. This module covers the broader sustainability context and global initiatives, the ESG market, environmental factors and mega trends, approaches to environmental analysis at country, sector, and company levels, and global, regional, local context.
